fields.descriptive_line: Food box of tinned copper, made in Syria or Egypt in the Mamluk period; Islamic metalwork
fields.physical_description: Food box and lid of rounded oblong shape, made of copper, hammered, engraved and tinned. The hasp and hinges are later additions.
fields.dimensions: Length: 16 in, Width: 9.5 in, Height: 5 in
fields.bibliography: L.A. Mayer, Saracenic Heraldry. A Survey, Oxford, 1933, pp.142-3, and pl.LXVIII. 9, 10 [= rubbings of one section of the inscription and of one blazon]. J.W. Allan, 'Later Mamluk Metalwork - II. A series of lunch-boxes', Oriental Art, xvii, no.2, 1971, pp.156-64.
fields.history_note:
The decoration includes a documentary inscription, repeated twice, and the blazon of the owner, repeated eight times.

The inscriptions record that the box was made for Zayn al-Din Khushqadam, who at the time of making was "the Vizier, Warden of the Noble Princesses, and Amir Treasurer". Mayer, using the chronicle of Ibn Ayas, identified him as a eunuch at the Mamluk court, whose career he reconstructed as follows:

AH 873 (AD 1468/9) - appointed Chief of the Corps of Cup-bearers
AH 879 (AD 1474) - appointed Vizier in succession to Yashbak al-Dawadar
Rabi' al-Awwal 882 (June or July 1477) - appointed Great Treasurer and Warden of the Princesses
AH 884 (AD 1479-80) - Amir al-Hajj for the Pilgrimage to Mecca that year
Rabi' al-Akhir 889 (April or May 1484) - dismissed as Vizier
Ramadan 891 (September 1486) - exiled to Qus
Muharram 894 (December 1488) - exiled to Sawakin
Shawwal 894 (August or September 1489) - died in Sawakin

Thus, the titulature used on the box shows that it was made between June 1477 and May 1484.

The blazon of Khushqadam shows a napkin in the upper field, a cup between two horns in the central field, and a cup in the lower field.

According to Allan, food boxes of this type were made in stacking sets of two or three, with a lid with a central handle. The lid could also serve as a serving dish, when the handle served as a foot. The step in the base, the arrangement of the decoration and the slight mismatch between the shapes of the box and the lid recorded by Allan suggest that in this case the box was the middle element in a stacking set of three. The original attachments designed to keep the stack closed and for carrying it were probably made of another material and have been lost. The current hasp and hinges were added later, perhaps when the box and lid were adapted as a single-unit set. The decoration of these elements suggest that this was done in the late Ottoman period.
fields.production_note: According to Allan, this is the only example of a late Mamluk food box of this type where the original owner is known to have resided in Cairo rather than Syria.
